Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Transnational Migration and the Global Circulation of Talent

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1519268
Liza Weinstein
Yingchan Zhang
Northeastern University

An increasing number of U.S.-educated Chinese have reportedly returned to China in recent years. Chinese state-run media emphasize the prosperous outlook for these returnees and the state's recognition of their importance for the country's transition to a knowledge economy. As Chinese cities compete to attract talented returnees, little is known about how the municipal strategies work and what roles returning skilled labor indeed play in Chinese cities' development. This dissertation research studies the ways in which Chinese cities recruit U.S.-educated Chinese talent to achieve their goal of stimulating urban development, and how these recruitment initiatives in turn affect the migration decisions and reincorporation experiences of the targeted returnees. This study addresses three questions: 1) how Chinese cities, in the hope of becoming global, recruit U.S.-trained Chinese talent back for development projects 2) how these recruitment programs affect the migration decisions of U.S-educated Chinese talent in the U.S. and the reincorporation experiences of the returnees in China 3) how the disjunctures between the ways the local Chinese state and the returnees conceptualize "value" and "contribution" influence the ways in which they interact with each other. To examine these themes, the researchers will conduct a case study of a major city in eastern China and utilize semi-structured interviews, participant observation and secondary analysis as the main methods of investigation.

This study has the following potential impacts. Firstly, it will contribute to social science research on urban development, global cities, and transnational migration by presenting a critical case for understanding the complexities of urban development in the neoliberal era and demonstrating how specific state development policies affect the relocation and settlement patterns of highly skilled professionals. Secondly, this study will provide implications for policy makers and urban planners. The findings will help cities that fiercely compete with each other in a globalizing world to better understand how the strategies of attracting talent work in practice and if these strategies do foster development. Moreover, this project will inform how to retain a highly competitive workforce that is globally mobile in nature in the contemporary era. As highly-skilled immigrants from Asia consist of an increasing part of the overall immigration to the U.S., it is essential for U.S. policy makers to understand these processes in order to make informed decisions about immigration reform in general and about policies to attract and retain highly skilled immigrants in particular.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary

This dissertation analyzes the intertwining dynamics of transnational migration and urban development in the context of globalization and economic reforms in China. Specifically, it examines how Chinese cities recruit U.S.-trained Chinese back for development projects, how these recruitment programs affect the migration decisions and reincorporation experiences of targeted returnees, and how the disjunctures between the ways in which the local Chinese state and the returnees conceptualize “value” and “contributions” influence their interactions with each other. This dissertation is based on fieldwork conducted in China for a total of eleven months between 2014 and 2016, with the city of Nanjing as the primary research site and some supplementary work conducted in the city of Hangzhou and the city of Suzhou. With the financial support from this National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement grant, the Co-PI was able to travel back to Nanjing and Hangzhou for a follow-up visit between April and June, 2016. The Co-PI conducted twenty follow-up interviews with project participants who the Co-PI had spoken with during the fieldwork in 2014 and 2015. In addition, the Co-PI carried out additional observation at the work sites of key informants and focused on the work culture at these sites and how return migrants interacted with their non-returnee colleagues. In the fall of 2016, additionally, the Co-PI also conducted semi-structured interviews with U.S.-trained Chinese in the Greater Boston Area who had decided to stay in the United States for the time being, as a comparison to the U.S.-educated returnees interviewed in China.    

Intellectual Merit

By investigating the specific ways in which Chinese cities stimulate return migration, this dissertation presents a critical case for understanding the complexities of urban development in the neoliberal era and reassessing the applicability of global city theory based on a non-Western experience. This dissertation also reveals that the short-term economic incentives of the migrants’ conflict with the long-term development vision of the Chinese state, and that the disjunctures between how Chinese cities and overseas returnees conceptualize urban development and the contributions of these highly-skilled returnees have created significant tensions at multiple levels. This research therefore demonstrates how specific state development policies affect the relocation and settlement patterns of skilled professionals that are highly mobile, and how the flexible arrangements of time, space and labor facilitated by neoliberal globalization are articulated on the ground.

Broader Impact

We have already started to disseminate the results of this dissertation. In 2016, the Co-PI presented preliminary findings at the 3rd International Sociological Association Forum of Sociology in Vienna, Austria in July and at the 111th American Sociological Association annual meeting and the Society for the Study of Social Problems annual meeting in Seattle in August. In 2017, abstracts based on research findings have been accepted by the Research Committee 21 of the International Sociological Association Conference in Leeds, U.K., in September, and by the Sociology of Development Conference in Detroit, MI in October.

Outside academia, this research provides important implications for policy makers and urban planners. The findings will help Chinese cities that fiercely compete with each other to better understand how the strategies of attracting talent work in practice and whether these strategies do foster development. Moreover, this project sheds important light on how to retain a highly competitive workforce that is globally mobile in nature in the contemporary era. As highly-skilled immigrants from Asia consist of an increasing part of the overall immigration to the U.S., this research will help U.S. policy makers better understand these processes in order to make informed decisions about immigration reform in general and about policies to attract and retain highly skilled immigrants in particular.
